I'm having a tough time telling what part is yours and what part is quoted... :(

And yes, I feel a little patient tonight. :)

So said Jason Rogers on 3/10/2003 --------------------
hee-hee, your answer was more patient. :)

On Mon, 2003-03-10 at 22:49, J. B. Rainsberger wrote: Do not use
Math.random() directly. Instead, hide it behind an interface that
provides a method like "getNextNumber()". In your tests, substitute an
implementation that answers an expected sequence of numbers. Give this
method as good a name as you can think of, given your problem domain.

In the case of a board game, for example, I would hide the randomization
behind an interface like DiceRoller with a method rollDice(). Then I
could have a deterministic implementation that answers a known sequence
of dice rolls and the randomized version that I would use in the real
game.

Good luck.

So said sudhir on 3/10/2003 --------------------
Hi

I am trying to write junit test cases for a class.
Some of the functions in the class use random numbers
by calling the function Math.random(). Is there any
way to verify the method.

Thank you

sudhir shakya
